DualFL:Â A Duality-based Federated Learning Algorithm with Communication Acceleration in the General Convex Regimeâ€ â€ thanks: Submitted to arXiv.\fundingThis work was supported by the KAUST Baseline Research Fund.

Jongho Park Computer, Electrical and Mathematical Science and Engineering Division, King Abdullah University of Science and TechnologyÂ (KAUST), Thuwal 23955, Saudi Arabia (, ). jongho.park@kaust.edu.sa xu@multigrid.org â€ƒâ€ƒ Jinchao Xu22footnotemark: 2 Department of Mathematics, Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, 16802, USA
Abstract

We propose a new training algorithm, named DualFLÂ (Dualized Federated Learning), for solving distributed optimization problems in federated learning. DualFL achieves communication acceleration for very general convex cost functions, thereby providing a solution to an open theoretical problem in federated learning concerning cost functions that may not be smooth nor strongly convex. We provide a detailed analysis for the local iteration complexity of DualFL to ensure the overall computational efficiency of DualFL. Furthermore, we introduce a completely new approach for the convergence analysis of federated learning based on a dual formulation. This new technique enables concise and elegant analysis, which contrasts the complex calculations used in existing literature on convergence of federated learning algorithms.

keywords:
Federated learning, Duality, Communication acceleration, Inexact local solvers
{AMS}

68W15, 90C46, 90C25

1 Introduction

This paper is devoted to a novel approach to design efficient training algorithms for federated learningÂ [34]. Unlike standard machine learning approaches, federated learning encourages each client to have its own dataset and to update a local correction of a global model maintained by an orchestrating server via the local dataset and a local training algorithm. Recently, federated learning has been considered as an important research topic in the field of machine learning as data becomes increasingly decentralized and privacy of individual data is an utmost importanceÂ [18, 31].

In federated learning, it is assumed that communication costs dominateÂ [34]. Hence, training algorithms for federated learning should be designed toward a direction that the amount of communication among the clients is reduced. For example, FedAvgÂ [34], one of the most popular training algorithms for federated learning, improves its communication efficiency by adopting local training. Namely, multiple local gradient descent steps instead of a single step are performed in each client before communication among the clients. In recent years, various local training approaches have been considered to improve the communication efficiency of federated learning; e.g., operator splittingÂ [42], dual averagingÂ [57], augmented LagrangianÂ [59], Douglasâ€“Rachfold splittingÂ [52], client-level momentumÂ [55], and sharpness-aware minimizationÂ [43]. Meanwhile, under some similarity assumptions on local cost functions, gradient sliding techniques can be adopted to reduce the computational burden of each client; seeÂ [23] and references therein.

An important observation made inÂ [19] is that data heterogeneity in federated learning can cause client drift, which in turn affects the convergence of federated learning algorithms. Indeed, it was observed inÂ [20, FigureÂ 3] that a large number of local gradient descent steps without shifting of the local gradient leads to solution nonconvergence. To address this issue, several gradient shift techniques that can compensate for client drift have been considered: ScaffoldÂ [19], FedDynÂ [1], S-Local-SVRGÂ [13], FedLinÂ [36], and ScaffnewÂ [35]. These techniques achieve linear convergence rates of the training algorithms through carefully designed gradient shift techniques.

Recently, it was investigated in a pioneering workÂ [35] that communication acceleration can be achieved by a federated learning algorithm if we use a tailored gradient shift scheme and a probabilistic approach for communication frequency. Specifically, it was shown that ScaffnewÂ [35] achieves the optimal ğ’ªâ€‹(Îºâ€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ’ªğœ…1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\kappa}\log(1/\epsilon))-communication complexity of distributed convex optimizationÂ [2] for the smooth strongly convex regime, where Îºğœ…\kappa is the condition number of the problem and Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon measures a target level of accuracy; see alsoÂ [17] for a tighter analysis. Since then, several federated learning algorithms with communication acceleration have been considered; to name a few, ProxSkip-VRÂ [33], APDA-InexactÂ [48], and RandProxÂ [12]. One may refer toÂ [33] for a historical survey on the theoretical progress of federated learning algorithms.

In this paper, we continue growing the list of federated learning algorithms with communication acceleration by proposing a novel algorithm called DualFLÂ (Dualized Federated Learning). The key idea is to establish a certain dualityÂ [46] between a model federated learning problem and a composite optimization problem. By the nature of composite optimization problemsÂ [39], the dual problem can be solved efficiently by a forward-backward splitting algorithm with the optimal convergence rateÂ [5, 11, 44]. By applying the predualization technique introduced inÂ [26, 28] to an optimal forward-backward splitting method for the dual problem, we obtain our proposed algorithm DualFL. While each individual technique used in this paper is not new, a combination of the techniques yields the following desirable results:

  • â€¢

    DualFL achieves the optimal Oâ€‹(Îºâ€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ‘‚ğœ…1italic-ÏµO(\sqrt{\kappa}\log(1/\epsilon))-communication complexity in the smooth strongly convex regime.

  • â€¢

    DualFL achieves communication acceleration even when the cost function is either nonsmooth or non-strongly convex.

  • â€¢

    DualFL can adopt any optimization algorithm as its local solver, making it adaptable to each clientâ€™s local problem.

  • â€¢

    Communication acceleration of DualFL is guaranteed in a deterministic manner. That is, both the algorithm and its convergence analysis do not rely on stochastic arguments.

In particular, we would like to highlight that DualFL is the first federated learning algorithm that achieves communication acceleration for cost functions that may not be smooth nor strongly convex. This solves an open theoretical problem in federated learning concerning communication acceleration for general convex cost functions. In addition, the duality technique used in the convergence analysis presented in this paper is completely new in the area of federated learning, and it provides concise and elegant analysis, distinguishing itself from prior existing works with intricate calculations.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we state a model federated learning problem. We introduce the proposed DualFL and its convergence properties in SectionÂ 3. In SectionÂ 4, we introduce a regularization technique for DualFL to deal with non-strongly convex problems. We establish connections to existing federated learning algorithms in SectionÂ 5. In SectionÂ 6, we establish a duality relation between DualFL and a forward-backward splitting algorithm applied to a certain dual formulation. We present numerical results of DualFL in SectionÂ 7. Finally, we discuss limitations of this paper in SectionÂ 8.

2 Problem description

In this section, we present a standard mathematical model for federated learning. In federated learning, it is assumed that each client possesses its own dataset, and that a local cost function is defined with respect to the dataset of each client. Hence, we consider the problem of minimizing the average of Nğ‘N cost functions stored on Nğ‘N clientsÂ [18, 19, 33]:

3 Main results

In this section, we present the main results of this paper: the proposed algorithm, called DualFL, and its convergence theorems. We now present DualFL in AlgorithmÂ 1 as follows.

DualFL updates the server parameter from Î¸(n)superscriptğœƒğ‘›\theta^{(n)} to Î¸(n+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘›1\theta^{(n+1)} by the following steps. First, each client computes its local solution Î¸j(n+1)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›1\theta_{j}^{(n+1)} by solving the local problemÂ (2) with several iterations of some local training algorithm. Note that, similar to ScaffoldÂ [19], FedLinÂ [36], and ScaffnewÂ [35], the local problemÂ (2) is defined in terms of the local control variate Î¶j(n)superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›\zeta_{j}^{(n)}. Then the server aggregates all the local solutions Î¸j(n+1)superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›1\theta_{j}^{(n+1)} by averaging them to obtain a new server parameter Î¸(n+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘›1\theta^{(n+1)}. After obtaining the new server parameter Î¸(n+1)superscriptğœƒğ‘›1\theta^{(n+1)}, it is transferred to each client, and the local control variate is updated usingÂ (4). The overrelaxation parameter Î²nsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›\beta_{n} inÂ (4) can be obtained by a simple recursive formulaÂ (5), which relies on the hyperparameter ÏğœŒ\rho. We note that a similar overrelaxation scheme was employed in APDA-InexactÂ [48].

One feature of the proposed DualFL is its flexibility in choosing local solvers for the local problemÂ (2). More precisely, the method allows for the adoption of any local solvers, making it adaptable to each local problem in a client. The same advantage was reported in several existing works such asÂ [1, 52, 59]. Another notable feature of DualFL is its fully deterministic nature, in contrast to some existing federated learning algorithms that rely on randomness to achieve communication accelerationÂ [12, 33, 35]. Specifically, DualFL does not rely on uncertainty to ensure communication acceleration, which enhances its reliability. Very recently, several federated learning algorithms that share the same advantage have been proposed; see, e.g.,Â [48].

3.1 Inexact local solvers

In DualFL, local problems of the formÂ (2) are typically solved inexactly using iterative algorithms. The resulting local solutions may deviate from the exact minimizers, and this discrepancy can affect the convergence behavior. Here, we present a certain inexactness assumption for local solvers that does not deteriorate the convergence properties of DualFL.

The following proposition is readily deduced by the Fenchelâ€“Rockafellar dualityÂ (see PropositionÂ 6.1).

3.2 Convergence theorems

The following theorem states that DualFL is provably convergent in the nonsmooth strongly convex regime if each local problem is solved so accurately that the primal-dual gap becomes less than a certain value. Moreover, DualFL achieves communication acceleration in the sense that the squared solution error â€–Î¸(n)âˆ’Î¸âˆ—â€–2superscriptnormsuperscriptğœƒğ‘›superscriptğœƒ2\|\theta^{(n)}-\theta^{*}\|^{2} at the nğ‘›nth communication round is bounded by ğ’ªâ€‹(1/n2)ğ’ª1superscriptğ‘›2\mathcal{O}(1/n^{2}), which is derived by momentum acceleration; see SectionÂ 6. As we are aware, DualFL is the first federated learning algorithm with communication acceleration that is convergent even if the cost function is nonsmooth. A proof of TheoremÂ 3.2 will be provided in SectionÂ 6.

TheoremÂ 3.3 implies that DualFL is linearly convergent with an acceptable rate 1âˆ’Ï1ğœŒ1-\sqrt{\rho} even if the hyperparameters were not chosen optimally. That is, the performance DualFL is robust with respect to a choice of the hyperparameters.

3.3 Local iteration complexity

We analyze the local iteration complexity of DualFL under the conditions of TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3. We recall that DualFL is compatible with any optimization algorithm as its local solver. Hence, we may assume that we use an optimal first-order optimization algorithm in the sense of Nemirovskii and NesterovÂ [37, 41]. That is, optimization algorithms of iteration complexity ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Ïµ)ğ’ª1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(1/\epsilon) and ğ’ªâ€‹(Îºâ€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ’ªğœ…1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\kappa}\log(1/\epsilon)) are considered in the cases corresponding to TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3. Based on this setting, we have the following results regarding the local iteration complexity of DualFL. Both theorems can be derived straightforwardly by substituting Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in the iteration complexity of local solvers with the threshold values given in TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3. Note that the number of outer iterations of DualFL to meet the target accuracy Ïµout>0subscriptitalic-Ïµout0\epsilon_{\mathrm{out}}>0 is ğ’ªâ€‹(1/Ïµout)ğ’ª1subscriptitalic-Ïµout\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{\epsilon_{\mathrm{out}}}) and ğ’ªâ€‹((1/Ï)â€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµout))ğ’ª1ğœŒ1subscriptitalic-Ïµout\mathcal{O}((1/\sqrt{\rho})\log(1/\epsilon_{\mathrm{out}})) in the cases of TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3, respectively.

Theorem 3.4.

Suppose that the assumptions given in TheoremÂ 3.2 hold. Similar to other state-of-the-art federated learning algorithmsÂ [12, 14, 35], the local iteration complexity of DualFL scales with Îºğœ…\sqrt{\kappa}. This implies that DualFL is computationally efficient, not only in terms of communication complexity but also in terms of total complexity.

4 Extension to non-strongly convex problems

The convergence properties of the proposed DualFL presented in SectionÂ 3 rely on the strong convexity of the cost function Eğ¸E inÂ (1). Although this assumption has been considered as a standard one in many existing works on federated learning algorithmsÂ [1, 19, 35, 48], it may not hold in practical settings and is often unrealistic. In this section, we deal with how to apply DualFL to non-strongly convex problems, i.e., when Eğ¸E is not assumed to be strongly convex. Throughout this section, we assume that each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}, 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N, in the model problemÂ (1) is not strongly convex. In this case,Â (1) admits nonunique solutions in general. For a positive real number Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0, we consider the following â„“2superscriptâ„“2\ell^{2}-regularizationÂ [38] ofÂ (1):

Then each fjÎ±superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—ğ›¼f_{j}^{\alpha} inÂ (10) is Î±ğ›¼\alpha-strongly convex. Hence, DualFL applied toÂ (10) satisfy the convergence properties stated in TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3. In particular, the sequence {Î¸(n)}superscriptğœƒğ‘›\{\theta^{(n)}\} generated by DualFL applied toÂ (10) converges to the unique solution Î¸Î±âˆˆÎ©superscriptğœƒğ›¼Î©\theta^{\alpha}\in\Omega ofÂ (10). 5 Comparison with existing algorithms and convergence theory

In this section, we discuss connections to existing federated learning algorithms. Based on the classification established inÂ [33], DualFL can be classified as a fifth-generation federated learning algorithm, which achieves communication acceleration. In the smooth strongly convex regime, DualFL achieves the ğ’ªâ€‹(Îºâ€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ’ªğœ…1italic-Ïµ\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{\kappa}\log(1/\epsilon))-communication complexity, which is comparable to other existing algorithms in the same generation such as ScaffnewÂ [35], APDA-InexactÂ [48], and RandProxÂ [12]. The optimal communication complexity of DualFL is achieved without relying on randomness; all the statements in the algorithm are deterministic. This feature is shared with some recent federated learning algorithms such as APDA-InexactÂ [48] and 5GCSÂ [14]. A distinct novelty of DualFL is its communication acceleration, even when the cost function is either nonsmooth or non-strongly convex. Among the existing fifth generation of federated learning algorithms, only RandProx has been proven to be convergent in the smooth non-strongly convex regime, with an Oâ€‹(1/n)ğ‘‚1ğ‘›O(1/n)-convergence rate of the energy errorÂ [12, TheoremÂ 11]. However, this rate is the same of those of federated learning algorithms without communication acceleration such as ScaffoldÂ [19] and FedDynÂ [1]. In contrast, DualFL achieves the Oâ€‹((1/Ïµ)â€‹logâ¡(1/Ïµ))ğ‘‚1italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµO((1/\sqrt{\epsilon})\log(1/\epsilon))-communication complexity with respect to the gradient error, which has not been achieved by the existing algorithms. Furthermore, not only communication acceleration but also convergence to a solution in the nonsmooth strongly convex regime have not been addressed by the existing fifth generation algorithms.

In the local problemÂ (2) of DualFL, we minimize not only the local cost function fjâ€‹(Î¸j)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘—subscriptğœƒğ‘—f_{j}(\theta_{j}) but also an additional term âˆ’Î½â€‹âŸ¨Î¶j(n),Î¸jâŸ©ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğœƒğ‘—-\nu\langle\zeta_{j}^{(n)},\theta_{j}\rangle. That is, âˆ’Î½â€‹Î¶j(n)ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›-\nu\zeta_{j}^{(n)} serves as a gradient shift to mitigate client drift and accelerate convergence. In this viewpoint, DualFL can be classified as a federated learning algorithm with gradient shift. This class includes other methods such as ScaffoldÂ [19], FedDynÂ [1], S-Local-SVRGÂ [13], FedLinÂ [36], and ScaffnewÂ [35]. Meanwhile, DualFL belongs to the class of primal-dual methods for federated learning, e.g., FedPDÂ [59], FedDRÂ [52], APDA-InexactÂ [48], and 5GCSÂ [14]. While almost of the existing methods utilize a consensus reformulation ofÂ (1)Â (seeÂ [35, EquationÂ (6)]), DualFL is based on a certain dual formulation ofÂ (1), as we will see in SectionÂ 6. More precisely, we will show that DualFL is obtained by applying predualizationÂ [26, 28] to an accelerated forward-backward splitting algorithmÂ [5, 11, 44] for the dual problem. The dual problem has a particular structure that makes the forward-backward splitting algorithm equivalent to the prerelaxed nonlinear block Jacobi methodÂ [29], which belongs to a broad class of parallel subspace correction methodsÂ [54] for convex optimizationÂ [40, 51].

TableÂ 1 provides an overview of the comparison between DualFL and other fifth-generation federated learning algorithms discussed above.

6 Mathematical theory

This section provides a mathematical theory for DualFL. We establish a duality relation between DualFL and an accelerated forward-backward splitting algorithmÂ [5, 11, 44] applied to a certain dual formulation of the model problemÂ (1). Utilizing this duality relation, we derive the convergence theorems presented in this paper, namely TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3. Moreover, the duality relation provides a rationale for naming the proposed algorithm as DualFL. Throughout this section, we may assume that each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} inÂ (1) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex, as DualFL for a non-strongly convex problem utilizes the strongly convex regularizationÂ (10).

6.1 Dual formulation

We introduce a dual formulation of the model federated learning problemÂ (1) that is required for the convergence analysis. For the sake of completeness, we first present key features of the Fenchelâ€“Rockafellar duality; see alsoÂ [11, 46]. domâ¡F={xâˆˆX:Fâ€‹(x)<âˆ}.domğ¹conditional-setğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ¹ğ‘¥\operatorname{dom}F=\left\{x\in X:F(x)<\infty\right\}.

Recall that the Legendreâ€“Fenchel conjugate of Fğ¹F is denoted by Fâˆ—:Xâ†’â„Â¯:superscriptğ¹â†’ğ‘‹Â¯â„F^{*}\colon X\rightarrow\overline{\mathbb{R}}, i.e.,

One may refer toÂ [46] for the elementary properties of the Legendreâ€“Fenchel conjugate. In PropositionÂ 6.1, we summarize the notion of the Fenchelâ€“Rockafellar dualityÂ [46, CorollaryÂ 31.2.1], which plays an important role in the convergence analysis of DualFL.

We note that problems of the formÂ (20) have been applied in some limited cases in machine learning, such as support vector machinesÂ [16] and logistic regressionÂ [56]. Very recently, the dual problemÂ (20) was utilized in federated learning inÂ [14].

Let ğƒâˆ—âˆˆÎ©NsuperscriptğƒsuperscriptÎ©ğ‘\boldsymbol{\xi}^{*}\in\Omega^{N} denote a solution ofÂ (20). InvokingÂ (18), we obtain the primal-dual relation

between the primal solution Î¸âˆ—superscriptğœƒ\theta^{*} and the dual solution ğƒâˆ—superscriptğƒ\boldsymbol{\xi}^{*}.

6.2 Inexact FISTA

For ğƒâˆˆÎ©NğƒsuperscriptÎ©ğ‘\boldsymbol{\xi}\in\Omega^{N}, let

Fdâ€‹(ğƒ)=12â€‹Nâ€‹Î½â€‹â€–âˆ‘j=1NÎ¾jâ€–2,Gdâ€‹(ğƒ)=âˆ‘j=1Ngjâˆ—â€‹(Î¾j).formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹dğƒ12ğ‘ğœˆsuperscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—2subscriptğºdğƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—subscriptğœ‰ğ‘—F_{\mathrm{d}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\frac{1}{2N\nu}\left\|\sum_{j=1}^{N}\xi_{j}\right\|^{2},\quad G_{\mathrm{d}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})=\sum_{j=1}^{N}g_{j}^{*}(\xi_{j}).

Then the dual problemÂ (20) is rewritten as the following composite optimization problemÂ [39]:

(22) minğƒâˆˆÎ©Nâ¡{Edâ€‹(ğƒ):=Fdâ€‹(ğƒ)+Gdâ€‹(ğƒ)}.subscriptğƒsuperscriptÎ©ğ‘assignsubscriptğ¸dğƒsubscriptğ¹dğƒsubscriptğºdğƒ\min_{\boldsymbol{\xi}\in\Omega^{N}}\left\{E_{\mathrm{d}}(\boldsymbol{\xi}):=F_{\mathrm{d}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})+G_{\mathrm{d}}(\boldsymbol{\xi})\right\}.

By the Cauchyâ€“Schwarz inequality, Fdsubscriptğ¹dF_{\mathrm{d}} is Î½âˆ’1superscriptğœˆ1\nu^{-1}-smooth. Moreover, under Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strong convexity and Lğ¿L-smoothness assumptions on each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}, GdsubscriptğºdG_{\mathrm{d}} is (Lâˆ’Î½)âˆ’1superscriptğ¿ğœˆ1(L-\nu)^{-1}-strongly convex if Î½âˆˆ(0,Î¼]ğœˆ0ğœ‡\nu\in(0,\mu]. SinceÂ (22) is a composite optimization problem, forward-backward splitting algorithms are well-suited to solve it. Among several variants of forward-backward splitting algorithms, we focus on an inexact version of FISTAÂ [5] proposed inÂ [44], which accommodates strongly convex objectives and inexact proximal operations. Inexact FISTA with the fixed step size Î½ğœˆ\nu applied toÂ (22) is summarized in AlgorithmÂ 2, in the form suitable for our purposes.

We state the convergence theorems of AlgorithmÂ 2, which are essential ingredients for the convergence analysis of DualFL. Recall that, if each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j} inÂ (1) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex and Î½âˆˆ(0,Î¼]ğœˆ0ğœ‡\nu\in(0,\mu], then Fdsubscriptğ¹dF_{\mathrm{d}} inÂ (22) is Î½âˆ’1superscriptğœˆ1\nu^{-1}-smooth. Hence, we have the following convergence theorem of AlgorithmÂ 2Â [44, CorollaryÂ 3.3].

Proposition 6.2.

Suppose that each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}, 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N, inÂ (1) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex for some Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0. In addition, suppose that the error sequence {Î´n}subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›\{\delta_{n}\} in AlgorithmÂ 2 is given by

The dual problemÂ (20) has a particular structure that allows AlgorithmÂ 2 to be viewed as a parallel subspace correction method for (20)Â [40, 51, 54]. That is, the proximal problemÂ (23) can be decomposed into Nğ‘N independent subproblems, each defined in terms of Î¾jsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—\xi_{j} for 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N. 6.3 Duality between DualFL and FISTA

An important observation is that there exists a duality relation between the sequences generated by AlgorithmÂ 2 and those generated by DualFL. In DualFL, we define two auxiliary sequences {ğƒ(n)}superscriptğƒğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} and {ğœ¼(n)}superscriptğœ¼ğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\eta}^{(n)}\} as follows:

(25a) Î¾j(n+1)superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘›1\displaystyle\xi_{j}^{(n+1)} =Î½â€‹(Î¶j(n)âˆ’Î¸j(n+1)),Î¾j(0)=0,formulae-sequenceabsentğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—00\displaystyle=\nu(\zeta_{j}^{(n)}-\theta_{j}^{(n+1)}),\quad\xi_{j}^{(0)}=0,
(25b) Î·j(n+1)superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘›1\displaystyle\eta_{j}^{(n+1)} =Î½â€‹(Î¶j(n+1)âˆ’(1+Î²n)â€‹Î¸(n+1)+Î²nâ€‹Î¸(n)),Î·j(0)=0,formulae-sequenceabsentğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›11subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—00\displaystyle=\nu(\zeta_{j}^{(n+1)}-(1+\beta_{n})\theta^{(n+1)}+\beta_{n}\theta^{(n)}),\quad\eta_{j}^{(0)}=0,

for nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0 and 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N. LemmaÂ 6.6 summarizes the duality relation between DualFL and AlgorithmÂ 2; the sequences {ğƒ(n)}superscriptğƒğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} and {ğœ¼(n)}superscriptğœ¼ğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\eta}^{(n)}\} defined inÂ (25) agree with those generated by AlgorithmÂ 2.

Lemma 6.6.

Suppose that each fjsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—f_{j}, 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N, inÂ (1) is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex for some Î¼>0ğœ‡0\mu>0. In addition, suppose that the number of local iterations for the jğ‘—jth client at the nğ‘›nth epoch of DualFL is large enough to satisfy

Î“n,jâ€‹(Î¸j(n+1))â‰¤Î´nNsuperscriptÎ“ğ‘›ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›1subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›ğ‘\Gamma^{n,j}(\theta_{j}^{(n+1)})\leq\frac{\delta_{n}}{N}

for some Î´n>0subscriptğ›¿ğ‘›0\delta_{n}>0Â (1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N, nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0). Proof 6.7.

(26) âˆ‘i=1NÎ¶i(n)=0,nâ‰¥0,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘›0ğ‘›0\sum_{i=1}^{N}\zeta_{i}^{(n)}=0,\quad n\geq 0,

which can be easily derived by mathematical induction withÂ (3) andÂ (4). Now, we take any nâ‰¥0ğ‘›0n\geq 0 and 1â‰¤jâ‰¤N1ğ‘—ğ‘1\leq j\leq N. By direct calculation, we obtain

âˆ‘i=1NÎ·i(n)=(â€‹25bâ€‹)Î½â€‹âˆ‘i=1NÎ¶i(n)âˆ’Î½â€‹Nâ€‹(1+Î²n)â€‹Î¸(n)+Î½â€‹Nâ€‹Î²nâ€‹Î¸(nâˆ’1)=(â€‹26â€‹)âˆ’Nâ€‹Î½â€‹(1+Î²n)â€‹Î¸(n)+Nâ€‹Î½â€‹Î²nâ€‹Î¸(nâˆ’1)=(â€‹25bâ€‹)Nâ€‹Î·j(n)âˆ’Nâ€‹Î½â€‹Î¶(n).superscriptitalic-(25bitalic-)superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘›ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘›ğœˆğ‘1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›ğœˆğ‘subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›1superscriptitalic-(26italic-)ğ‘ğœˆ1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›ğ‘ğœˆsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›1superscriptitalic-(25bitalic-)ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘ğœˆsuperscriptğœğ‘›\begin{split}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\eta_{i}^{(n)}&\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eta}}}{{=}}\nu\sum_{i=1}^{N}\zeta_{i}^{(n)}-\nu N(1+\beta_{n})\theta^{(n)}+\nu N\beta_{n}\theta^{(n-1)}\\ &\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{zeta_sum}}}{{=}}-N\nu(1+\beta_{n})\theta^{(n)}+N\nu\beta_{n}\theta^{(n-1)}\\ &\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eta}}}{{=}}N\eta_{j}^{(n)}-N\nu\zeta^{(n)}.\end{split}

Hence, we get

(27) Î½â€‹Î¶j(n)=Î·j(n)âˆ’1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1NÎ·i(n).ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘–ğ‘›\nu\zeta_{j}^{(n)}=\eta_{j}^{(n)}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\eta_{i}^{(n)}.

CombiningÂ (6),Â (27), and LemmaÂ 6.4 implies that {ğ›(n)}superscriptğ›ğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} and {ğ›ˆ(n)}superscriptğ›ˆğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\eta}^{(n)}\} satisfyÂ (23). On the other hand, we obtain by direct calculation that

(1+Î²n)â€‹Î¾j(n+1)âˆ’Î²nâ€‹Î¾j(n)=(â€‹25aâ€‹)Î½â€‹(1+Î²n)â€‹(Î¶j(n)âˆ’Î¸j(n+1))âˆ’Î½â€‹Î²nâ€‹(Î¶j(nâˆ’1)âˆ’Î¸j(n))=(â€‹4â€‹)Î½â€‹Î¶j(n+1)âˆ’Î½â€‹(1+Î²n)â€‹Î¸(n+1)âˆ’Î½â€‹Î²nâ€‹Î¸(n)=(â€‹25bâ€‹)Î·j(n+1),superscriptitalic-(25aitalic-)1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘›1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘—ğ‘›ğœˆ1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›1ğœˆsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘—ğ‘›superscriptitalic-(4italic-)ğœˆsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—ğ‘›1ğœˆ1subscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›1ğœˆsubscriptğ›½ğ‘›superscriptğœƒğ‘›superscriptitalic-(25bitalic-)superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘—ğ‘›1\begin{split}(1+\beta_{n})\xi_{j}^{(n+1)}-\beta_{n}\xi_{j}^{(n)}&\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{xi}}}{{=}}\nu(1+\beta_{n})(\zeta_{j}^{(n)}-\theta_{j}^{(n+1)})-\nu\beta_{n}(\zeta_{j}^{(n-1)}-\theta_{j}^{(n)})\\ &\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{zeta}}}{{=}}\nu\zeta_{j}^{(n+1)}-\nu(1+\beta_{n})\theta^{(n+1)}-\nu\beta_{n}\theta^{(n)}\\ &\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\eqref{eta}}}{{=}}\eta_{j}^{(n+1)},\end{split}

which implies that {ğ›(n)}superscriptğ›ğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} and {ğ›ˆ(n)}superscriptğ›ˆğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\eta}^{(n)}\} satisfyÂ (24). This completes the proof.

LemmaÂ 6.6 implies that DualFL is a predualizationÂ [26, 28] of AlgorithmÂ 2. Namely, DualFL can be constructed by transforming the dual sequence {ğƒ(n)}superscriptğƒğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} generated by AlgorithmÂ 2 into the primal sequence {Î¸(n)}superscriptğœƒğ‘›\{\theta^{(n)}\} by leveraging the primal-dual relationÂ (21).

6.4 Proofs of TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3

Finally, the main convergence theorems for DualFL, TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3, can be derived by combining the optimal convergence properties of AlgorithmÂ 2 presented in PropositionsÂ 6.2 andÂ 6.3 and the duality relation presented in LemmaÂ 6.6.

Proof 6.8 (Proof of TheoremsÂ 3.2 andÂ 3.3).

Thanks to LemmaÂ 6.6, the sequence {ğ›(n)}superscriptğ›ğ‘›\{\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(n)}\} defined inÂ (25a) satisfies the convergence properties given in PropositionsÂ 6.2 andÂ 6.3, i.e.,

7 Numerical experiments

In this section, we present numerical results that demonstrate the performance of DualFL. All the algorithms were programmed using MATLABÂ R2022b and performed on a desktop equipped with AMD RyzenÂ 5 5600X CPUÂ (3.7GHz, 6C), 40GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTXÂ 1660 SUPER GPU with 6GB GDDR6 memory, and the operating system WindowsÂ 10 Pro.

As benchmarks, we choose the following recent federated learning algorithms: FedPDÂ [59], FedDRÂ [52], FedDualAvgÂ [57], FedDynÂ [1], ScaffnewÂ [35], APDA-InexactÂ [48], and 5GCSÂ [14]. All the hyperparameters appearing in these algorithms and DualFL are tuned by a grid search; see TableÂ 2 for details of the tuned hyperparameters.

Remark 7.1.

While we also conducted experiments with several primal federated learning algorithms such as FedAvgÂ [34], FedCMÂ [55], and FedSAMÂ [43], which do not rely on duality in their mechanisms, we do not present their results as their performances were not competitive compared to other methods.

To solve the local problems encountered in these algorithms, we employ the optimized gradient method with adaptive restartÂ (AOGM) proposed inÂ [21], with the stop criterion in which the algorithm terminates when the relative energy difference becomes less than 10âˆ’12superscript101210^{-12}. In each iteration of AOGM, the step size is determined using the full backtracking scheme introduced inÂ [10].

To test the performance of the algorithms, we use multinomial logistic regression problem, which is stated as

(31) minÎ¸=(w,b)âˆˆâ„dÃ—kÃ—â„kâ¡{1nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1nlogâ¡(âˆ‘l=1ke(wlâ‹…xj+bl)âˆ’(wyjâ‹…xj+byj))+Î¼2â€‹â€–Î¸â€–2},subscriptğœƒğ‘¤ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘’â‹…subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘™subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ğ‘™â‹…subscriptğ‘¤subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptğ‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—ğœ‡2superscriptnormğœƒ2\min_{\theta=(w,b)\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times k}\times\mathbb{R}^{k}}\left\{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{j=1}^{n}\log\left(\sum_{l=1}^{k}e^{(w_{l}\cdot x_{j}+b_{l})-(w_{y_{j}}\cdot x_{j}+b_{y_{j}})}\right)+\frac{\mu}{2}\|\theta\|^{2}\right\},

InÂ (31), we set the regularization parameter Î¼=10âˆ’2ğœ‡superscript102\mu=10^{-2}. We use the MNISTÂ [27]Â (k=10ğ‘˜10k=10, n=60,000ğ‘›60000n=60,000, d=28Ã—28ğ‘‘2828d=28\times 28) and CIFAR-10Â [24]Â (k=10ğ‘˜10k=10, n=60,000ğ‘›60000n=60,000, d=32Ã—32Ã—3ğ‘‘32323d=32\times 32\times 3) training datasets. Numerical results are presented in Fig.Â 1. Fig.Â 1(a, d) displays the convergence behavior of the benchmark algorithms, along with DualFL, when N=23ğ‘superscript23N=2^{3}. While the linear convergence rate of DualFL appears to be similar to those of FedPD, FedDR, and Scaffnew, the energy curve of DualFL is consistently lower than those of the other algorithms because DualFL achieves faster energy decay in the first several iterations, similar to FedDyn. That is, the DualFL loss decays as fast as FedDyn in the first several iterations, and then the linear decay rate of DualFL becomes similar to those of FedPD, FedDR, and Scaffnew. Fig.Â 1(b, e) verifies that the convergence rate of DualFL does not deteriorate even if the number of clients Nğ‘N becomes large. That is, DualFL is robust to a large number of clients. Finally, Fig.Â 1(c, f) illustrates the convergence behavior of DualFL under the condition where Î½ğœˆ\nu is fixed by Î¼ğœ‡\mu, and the value of ÏğœŒ\rho are varied. It can be seen that even when ÏğœŒ\rho is chosen far from its tuned value, the convergence rate of DualFL does not deteriorate significantly. This verifies the robustness of DualFL with respect to hyperparameter tuning.

8 Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed a new federated learning algorithm, called DualFL, based on the duality between the model federated learning problem and a composite optimization problem. We demonstrated that DualFL achieves communication acceleration, even in cases where the cost function lacks smoothness or strong convexity. This is the first result in the field of federated learning regarding communication acceleration of general convex cost functions. Through numerical experiments, we further confirmed that DualFL outperforms several recent federated learning algorithms.

8.1 Limitations and future works

A major limitation of this paper is that all the results are based on the convex setting. Although this limitation is also present in many recent works on federated learning algorithmsÂ [12, 35, 48], the nonconvex setting should be considered in future research to cover a wider range of practical machine learning tasks.

While our primary emphasis in this paper lies in enhancing the communication efficiency of training algorithms, we recognize that there are other critical aspects of federated learning, particularly concerning the stochastic nature of machine learning problemsÂ [53]. Stochasticity can manifest in various aspects of federated learning, including stochastic local training algorithms, client sampling, and communication compressionÂ [14, 15]. We have successfully tackled the aspect of stochastic local training algorithms in our paper, as DualFL has the flexibility to adopt various local solvers. However, challenges remain in addressing client sampling and communication compression. We anticipate that our results can be extended to incorporate client sampling by building upon existing works, such asÂ [32, 45], which focus on accelerated randomized block coordinate descent methods. Additionally, considering that communication compression can be modeled using stochastic gradientsÂ [13], we consider extending our results by designing an appropriate acceleration scheme for stochastic gradients as a future work.
